sourcing.instructions: Erbium oxide (Er2O3) from chemical suppliers; Oxygen source (O2) from gas suppliers; Titanium powder from metal suppliers; Thulium oxide (Tm2O3) from chemical suppliers; Yttrium oxide (Y2O3) from chemical suppliers.
steps: Erbium oxide (Er2O3) from chemical suppliers; Oxygen source (O2) from gas suppliers; Titanium powder from metal suppliers; Thulium oxide (Tm2O3) from chemical suppliers; Yttrium oxide (Y2O3) from chemical suppliers.

1. Weigh out 80 g of erbium oxide and 160 g of oxygen in a fume hood. 2. Measure 40 g of titanium powder and 10 g of thulium oxide. 3. Measure 10 g of yttrium oxide. 4. Combine all powdered materials in a ceramic or glass mixing container. 5. Use a mortar and pestle to thoroughly mix until homogeneous.
preparation.raw_text: 1. Weigh out 80 g of erbium oxide and 160 g of oxygen in a fume hood. 2. Measure 40 g of titanium powder and 10 g of thulium oxide. 3. Measure 10 g of yttrium oxide. 4. Combine all powdered materials in a ceramic or glass mixing container. 5. Use a mortar and pestle to thoroughly mix until homogeneous.

steps: 1. Transfer the mixture into a high-temperature crucible. 2. Place the crucible in a furnace. 3. Heat to 1200°C at a rate of 5°C/min. 4. Hold at 1200°C for 2 hours to ensure complete reaction.
heating.raw_text: 1. Transfer the mixture into a high-temperature crucible. 2. Place the crucible in a furnace. 3. Heat to 1200°C at a rate of 5°C/min. 4. Hold at 1200°C for 2 hours to ensure complete reaction.

steps: 1. After heating, turn off the furnace and allow it to cool naturally to room temperature. This process may take approximately 6-8 hours. 2. Ensure the crucible is not disturbed during cooling to prevent cracking.
cooling.raw_text: 1. After heating, turn off the furnace and allow it to cool naturally to room temperature. This process may take approximately 6-8 hours. 2. Ensure the crucible is not disturbed during cooling to prevent cracking.

steps: 1. Remove the solid sample from the crucible carefully. 2. If necessary, use a diamond saw to trim the sample to exact dimensions (3 inches x 2 inches x 7 inches). 3. Sand the edges and surfaces using fine-grit sandpaper for a smooth finish. 4. Optionally, seal the surface with a clear epoxy resin for added durability.
